bestBHT.bht: In this scene, the people gathered to eat, sitting on the ground in the month of flowers, as Jewish tradition dictated. Despite the parched grass in the midsummer wilderness, Jesus's provision for the people was unwavering. He demonstrated his deep understanding and compassion by providing for the crowd without any need for further consultation with his disciples, disregarding the smallness of the provisions at hand.

Marvin Vincent: It was then the month of flowers.
According to the Jewish ordinance, the head of the house was to speak the blessing only if he himself shared in the meal.
Philip Schaff: On the ground, not 'on the grass'...
They were 'in a wilderness', a desolate region, in this case.
The correct reading joins this verse closely with Matthew 15:36.
Archibald T. Robertson: On the ground (επ την γην). No mention of "grass" as in Matthew 14:19 for this time, midsummer, the grass would be parched and gone.
John Gill: Not regarding the smallness of the provisions, nor any further consulting with his disciples...

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, the people sat on the ground as they prepared to eat, which was significant because it was the month of flowers and the grass would have been parched. The head of the house, in accordance with Jewish tradition, spoke the blessing because he himself shared in the meal. It is also important to note that they were in a wilderness, a desolate region, at the time. Despite the smallness of the provisions, Jesus did not hesitate to provide for the people, without any further consultation with his disciples.

The people gathered to eat, sitting on the ground in the month of flowers. Following Jewish customs, the head of the house spoke the blessing as he shared in the meal. Surrounded by wilderness, Jesus provided for the people without hesitation, disregarding the smallness of the provisions. There was no need for further consultation with his disciples, reflecting his deep understanding and compassion.

As the people prepared to eat, they sat on the ground, as was customary during the month of flowers. In keeping with Jewish tradition, the head of the house would offer the blessing, only doing so if he took part in the meal himself. The parched grass in the midsummer wilderness was not a hindrance to Jesus' provision for the people, as he provided for them without any further consultation with his disciples, displaying his deep care and understanding.

In this scene, the people gathered to eat, sitting on the ground in the month of flowers, as Jewish tradition dictated. Despite the parched grass in the midsummer wilderness, Jesus's provision for the people was unwavering. He demonstrated his deep understanding and compassion by providing for the crowd without any need for further consultation with his disciples, disregarding the smallness of the provisions at hand.

The people found themselves seated on the ground, observing the Jewish custom during the month of flowers as they prepared to eat. Even though the wilderness was dry and devoid of grass, Jesus showed unwavering provision for the multitude. In an act of deep care and understanding, Jesus provided for the people without needing to consult his disciples further, disregarding the smallness of the provisions at hand.
